translated: Jātaka🔽Thirty-Third Chapter🔽The Chapter about Desires

analyzed: ki chanda vagga  ki chanda jātaka
translated: The Kiṁchandha Jātaka
“What is your desire, what is your aim,
that you are alone, meditating in the forest?
What do you hope for, what do you seek,
for what purpose do you live, brahmin?”
“Just as a great rain-cloud,
a pot well-rounded,🔽so too a ripe mango,
supreme in colour, smell, and taste.

analyzed: tam vuyhamānam sotena  disvānām alam ajjhime  pāṇīhi nam
translated: Seeing it, clean and in the middle,🔽being carried along by the water,🔽I took it in my hands
and brought it to my fire-sanctuary.
Then, having placed it on a plantain leaf,🔽I myself

analyzed: nikkhipitvā sayam aha  satthena nam vikappetvā
translated: cut it up with a knife,

analyzed: khuppipāsam ahāsi me  saḥ ham apetadaratho
translated: and it satisfied my hunger and thirst.🔽I, free from distress,
having become tranquil, able to endure pain,
do not attain satisfaction
in any other fruits.
Surely, after dying,
it will bring me back to life,
the mango, whose fruit is sweet,
with a delicious, delightful taste;
which I rescued, being carried along,
from the great ocean, the water.
I have told you everything,
because I am observing the fast,
I am sitting here, dear,
with a multitude of many-hued deer.

analyzed: tvam ca kho mā iva akkhāhi
translated: But you, who have not fled,
tell me who you are;
What are you, lovely lady,
or whose are you, good lady?
You are like a statue of gold,

analyzed: byagghī iva giri sānu jā  yāḥ santi nāriyaḥ devesu
translated: like a tigress on a mountain slope;🔽Among the women in the heavens,
who are the attendants of the gods,
And in the human world,
women who have come with beauty;
There is no one equal to you in beauty,
among the gods, gandhabbas, and humans;
You who are asked by me, with a beautiful brow,
tell me your name and your lineage”.
“The one you are sitting with, dear,
the beautiful Kosiki, brahmin;
I am the one who has arisen from the Bhusālaya,

analyzed: vara vāri vaha ughasā  nānā duma gaṇa ākiṇṇā
translated: the one with the best of the best of the currents.🔽Filled with many different kinds of birds,
with many mountain caves,
I am the foremost of them,
they gather around me in the cold season.
And also many forest streams,
with blue waters and rocky barriers,
with many elephant-frequented pools,
they gather around me with water.
Those with mango, rose-apple, and jujube trees,
with neem, date, and cottonwood trees;
with many kinds of fruit,
They bring it down in a steady flow.

original: Yaṁ kiñci ubhato tīre,🔽phalaṁ patati ambuni;
analyzed: yam kiñci ubhatas tīre  phalam patati ambuni
translated: Whatever fruit falls on both banks,🔽In the water of the river;
Without a doubt that fruit is the river’s,
The fruit that follows the current.
The wise one, knowing this,
Listen to me, one of great wisdom;
Do not delight in attachment,
Do not oppose the people, lord of the people.

original: Na vāhaṁ vaḍḍhavaṁ maññe,🔽Yaṁ tvaṁ raṭṭhābhivaḍḍhana;
analyzed: na vā aham vaḍḍhavam maññe  yam tvam raṭṭha abhivaḍḍhana
translated: I do not think you are prospering,🔽That you are prospering in the kingdom;🔽Being asked, O king,
You long for death.
His fathers know this,
The gandhabbas and the gods;
And those who are sages in the world,
Self-controlled and austere;
Without a doubt they also know,
The famous ones who have attained the path.”
“Having understood thus, the wise one, all things being known,
The destruction and passing away of life;
The evil of that man does not increase,

analyzed: sace na ceta iti vadhāya tassa
translated: If he does not intend to kill him.
In the assembly of sages,
Thus the worldly one is known by mindfulness;
In the company of the ignoble,
You seek to do evil.
If I were to die,
On your bank, O river, with its scattered red earth;
No doubt that will be the case,
when I am dead and gone.
Therefore, I will guard against
evil deeds, as if they were my own flesh.
Do not let all the people later
blame me when I am dead.”
“This is unknown to me, O you who are not in control,
I give you myself and my son.
Abandoning these evil sensual qualities,
you are intent on peace and the Dhamma.
He who, having abandoned former bonds,
later stands in bonds,
and practices contrary to the Dhamma,
his evil increases.
Come, I will lead you to
the cool waters,
I will lead you to the cool waters,
live mindfully.
With flowers and trees,
with Vakkalis, O subduer of the foe;
With geese, peacocks, and heavenly birds,
with Kola, rice, honey, and sugarcane;
With the cries of flocks of geese,
with cuckoos that awaken here.
Here the mango trees are full of branches,
like palm trees with their leaves removed;
Kosambas, Sallas, and Nīpas,
hanging down like ripe palm fruits.”
“With garlands, anklets, and bracelets,
with necklaces, and sandalwood cream;
By night you enjoyed yourself,
by day you suffered pain.
You had sixteen thousand women,
who were your attendants.
You were so powerful,
so wonderful, so hair-raising.
What evil deed did you do in the past,
that brought you suffering?
What did you do among humans
that you now eat your own back-flesh?”
“Having accepted a wife,
I was attached to sensual pleasures.
For a long time I wandered
to the detriment of others.
He who is a back-flesh-eater,
eats so greedily,
as I now eat
my own back-flesh.”
The Kiṁchandajātaka (1st)_
